descript.abstract: The USGS National Wildlife Health Center's (NWHC) EPIZOO database is a long term data set that documents over40 years of information on epizootics (epidemics) in wildlife. EPIZOO tracks die-offs throughout the United States and territories, primarily in migratory birds and endangered species. Data include locations, dates, species involved, history, population numbers, total numbers of sick and dead animals, and diagnostic information. Regular data are available from 1975 to the present; some data are available from earlier years. These data represent the most comprehensive documentation of the geographic occurrence of diseases in free-ranging wildlife in existence today. The data are collected from a reporting network developed at NWHC as well as from collaborators across the North American continent.
descript.purpose: Natural resource managers, regulators, the scientific community, and the public sector rely on data referencing contaminants, causes of mortality, epizootic events and disease agents to help make sound decisions regarding disease prevention and control, ecosystem management, habitat restoration, threatened and endangered species recovery planning and pesticide regulation, and to determine areas for future scientific investigation.
descript.supplinf:
EPIZOO is network-based, allowing simultaneous access by multiple NWHC users; raw data are not currently accessible outside the Center. However, a subset of recent NWHC data is available on the NWHC website here: http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/mortality_events/ongoing.jsp. Compilations of the data by quarter are available here: http://www.nwhc.usgs.gov/publications/quarterly_reports/index.jsp
This dataset is not for a single research project, with a study plan, a defined time frame, and a finite number of options for collecting, storing and analyzing data. This is a long term dataset documenting wildlife mortality and has been growing, changing and evolving over the last 40 years. The number of people involved in providing and processing information over the years reaches into the thousands.

keywtax.taxonkt: Most of the records in this dataset represent specimens covered under the Kingdom Animalia in the Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS, www.itis.gov). However, ancillary information is available on microbes, plants and fungi where these contributed to or caused morbidity or mortality in the primary specimen of interest.

citeinfo.title: Smithsonian field guide to the birds of North America
Peterson Field Guides: A Field Guide to the Birds: a Completely New Guide to All the Birds of Eastern and Central North America
Peterson Field Guides: A Field Guide to Western Birds
Peterson Field Guides: A Field guide to Reptiles and Amphibians: Eastern and Central North America
Peterson Field Guides: A Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians

cntperp.cntper: USGS National Wildlife Health Center personnel

taxonsys.taxoncom: Species were coded to the lowest taxonomic category possible - since we are dealing with dead animals, in some cases, decomposition only allowed for coding to order or family. However, in most cases, specimens were coded to genus/species and in some cases to subspecies. All codes are mapped to ITIS.

idinfo.accconst: Some information in this data file is part of confidential legal cases; it may be used in pending litigation and cannot be released.
idinfo.useconst: Acknowledgement of NWHC is requested in products derived from this data.

attracc.attraccr: The information in EPIZOO is derived from reports from external sources. An attempt is made to contact sources and verify information; however, the accuracy of data in these reports cannot always be determined. All data are then summarized and entered in a standard format. Once the information is entered, several systems are in place to ensure data consistency. Also, reports are published on a quarterly basis, allowing for external review.

dataqual.logic: Database records are checked routinely to ensure data integrity.
dataqual.complete: The following are included in the master database but are not published: pending legal cases, sensitive information or incomplete cases.

horizpa.horizpar: No formal positional accuracy tests were conducted

method.methdesc: Collaborators from federal, state, tribal and private agencies provide information for the system through personal contacts with Field Investigation Team members. Additional information, particularly for historical events, is captured from published reports in accredited journals, or reports from federal resource managers.

procstep.procdesc: There has been no statistical analysis or manipulation, other than quality control tests, performed on these data.

spdoinfo.indspref: INCITS 38:2009 U.S. state codes INCITS 31:2009 U.S. county codes SCCAI 2011 for international country codes and Canadian 2nd and 3rd geographic entities (based on ISO 3166-1)

enttyp.enttypd: Used to connect all tables in the main database.

attr.attrdef: Unique identifier for a wildlife mortality event (epizoo). In form, a four digit year identifier followed by a dash and a sequential number identifying the event (e.g. 2004-001) *

attrdomv.udom: Unique identifier for a wildlife mortality event (epizoo). In form, a four digit year identifier followed by a dash and a sequential number identifying the event (e.g. 2004-001) *

attr.attrdef: Initials identifying NWHC contact for the mortality event.

edom.edomv: Initials identifying NWHC contact for the mortality event.
edom.edomvd: Restricted list - linked to external lookup table (lCtrPeople)

attr.attrdef: Identifier for the US Fish and Wildlife Service administrative region in which the mortality event occurred. Values are 1-7.
Identifier for the US Geological Survey ecoregion in which the mortality event occurred. Values are E (east), C (central), and W (west).

edom.edomvd: Identifier for the US Geological Survey ecoregion in which the mortality event occurred.

attr.attrdef: Identifier for the flyway in which the mortality event occurred. Values are ATL (Atlantic), MIS (Mississippi, CEN (Central), and PAC (Pacific)

edom.edomvd: Identifier for the flyway in which the mortality event occurred.

attr.attrdef: Beginning date for the mortality event. Date format is xx/xx/xxxx, e.g. 12/23/2004

attr.attrdef: Indicates the group affiliation (e.g. FWS) for the person who contacted the Center about the mortality event.

edom.edomvd: Default is blank, check mark indicates yes.

attr.attrdef: Number for total dead (all species) throughout the event.

attrdomv.udom: Number for total dead (all species) throughout the event.

attr.attrdef: Identifies if FinalMortality figure is actual or an estimate. Default is blank, check mark indicates yes (it is an estimate).

edom.edomvd: Default is blank, check mark indicates yes (it is an estimate).

distinfo.distliab: Although these data have been processed successfully on a computer system at the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the accuracy or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from a U.S. Geological Survey server, and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. It is also strongly recommended that careful attention be paid to the contents of the metadata file associated with these data. The U.S. Geological Survey shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein.
